text: Bottle, thanks to grownfool. Reddish., with no head to speak of. Smells nice - bourbon and vanilla. Taste is winey-er than I expected, some grape, some more bourbon. dry, woody finish.

Bottle into a snifter. Muddy milk chocolate-brown. Bubbles come and go within seconds, leaving a still-looking liquid below. Smells almost sour. Lots of vinegar, green oak, green apple, white grapes, caramel, cherry. The flavor, however, is kind of light, not much to it. A green apple tartness. Splash of sour cherry. Very highly carbonated -- its almost hard to pick up the flavor with all these bubbles keeping the beer off my tongue. Light body, no noticeable alcohol. Meh. Too highly carbonated, weak flavor.
sample from bottle at 2014 houston big brew fest. Deep golden orange with small head. Tart, almost sour. Fruity with some wine element. Good funk. I really liked this one.

Pours golden with small tan head out of bottle. Aroma of sour cherries and sour yeast. Flavor of Chardonnay with finish of sour cherries. Good beer overall but I was wishing it would be more sour. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
BTBF. Clear amber pour. Tart aroma, woody, sour and fruity. Tart and sour flavor, dark fruit.

Bottle. Clear red amber, large beige head that dissipates fairly quickly leaving some lacing. Aroma is vinous, red wine, oak, cherries, supplication, perhaps a touch of funk. Really nice. Flavor is not quite up to aroma, but still very nice, Oaky vinous, tart cherry notes. Light initial sweetness dries out quickly, leaving light tartness. Minimal funk. Lightish body. High carbonation is a distraction. Let this one sit a bit. Ahh, gains a bit of funk from the dregs, as well as a cloudiness. Better rounded flavors that way. Brian would be proud of me.
Bright reddish-amber with a big beige head. Sour, fruity, bourbon barrel aroma. Tart, woody, fruity flavor, surprisingly weak. Medium bodied and dry with a lot of carbonation.
Missed the original release so glad to get a taste now. Pours deep garnet red with little head. Taste leans tart but not mouth puckering.

This isnt an old ale, in my opnion this is a Sour/Wild/Saison. Shared with Jrob21. Pours muddy pear with dissipating fizzy head. Scent is wine, berries, and booze. Flavor is sweet and earthy with biting finish. Fizzy light body that suits this beer well. Loved it. Hope Saint Arnolds brings it back. Bottle - Received in Trade

12 oz shared by ericteusink. Dry Chardonnay definitely there. Very effervescent. Cool red collor with lots of white head. Finish is a bit tangy and sour some light fruit. Tangerine. Not getting any old ale bit call it what you will.

12 ounce bottle from Secret Santa. Thanks! Pours a hazy dark amber color with a thin frothy white head. Decent head retention. Aroma of tart cherries and stone fruits, caramel, wine and a bit of funk. The taste is toasted malt, caramel, tart cherries, mild funk and a bit of pineapple. Medium bodied, slight booze, low carbonation. Solid.

On tap at st Arnold's. Pours a hazy golden/amber hue with average sized off-white head. Aroma is vinous, plum, cherries, lemon, acidic, oak. Taste of booze, lemon/grapefruit, tart, plum, oak, vanilla, and light pepper. Very tasty and unique. Almost a mild sour, but some sweetness to it that I can't put a label on.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Aroma: Tart Cherry, Cranberry, Oaky, Mild Chardonnay

Appearance: Orangish/Amber Hue, Passes Some Light, Off White Head, Some Lacing

Taste: Oaky, Tart Cherry, Mild Chardonnay, Mild Oranges

Mouthfeel: Decent Carbonation, Medium Bodied, Semi Drying
UPDATED: MAR 12, 2014 GABF 2013. Great wine aromas, cherry, and funk. Very smooth, with a short finish that almost comes off as as sweet.   Brett version.

Bottle from Rosebud Butternuts! Pours blood orange amber with a transient creamy off-white head. Aroma is wood and cooking cherry. Med minus body. Flavor is wood, wine, cooking cherry. Very refined for what amounts to a sour. Quite elegant and tasty.
Bottle shared by bhensonb. Pours reddish brown with a disappearing beige head and a marvelous Fruit and oak aroma. There is a smooth sour cherry and dark molasses flavor with a chardonnay finish.

Bottle at Square Burger. Pours a ruby amber with a thin white head. The aromas are cherries, acidic and kinda like a sour aroma. The mouthfeel is sweet, kinda syrupy and tart with a light body and lots of carbonation. Great beer. Cheers!

Not a bad offering. This reminded me of a mild sour ale. The aroma was sour and musty but with a malty character to it. The color was a dark brown with little to no head. Mild weight with some dryness in the finish. Carbonation was a little below average. Good mix of flavors with a tartness being ever present. Grainy notes with a fruitiness that was subtle. Not much of a hops presence. Interesting.

Rated at Big Texas Beer Fest, April 2013 - Amber in color with an average sized off-white head. Aroma is vinous, plum, cherries, lemon, acidic. Taste is of booze, lemon, tart, plum, wood, and light pepper.
Bottle thanks to Hopscotch.  Clear amber pour with a white head.  Slightly sour with good body, balance, and carbonation.
Bottle courtesy of t0rino, thanks!  Cloudy pale amber color, large beige head. Aroma of boozy butterscotch and caramel. Taste is smooth and fruity caramel.

12oz bottle. Aroma is a sweet white wine aroma with a hint of caramel malt. The appearance is a amber brown color.  The taste starts out with a sweet to sour flavor. Very interesting. After the sour you catch a malt flavor then finishes sour. The palate is a muted sour taste. Overall, a good product. Well done barreled beer.  

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Poured a copper color with a nice white head.  Aroma had a light funk to it.  Taste had noticeable cherry notes with nice bretty-tart-funky edges.  The third fantastic beer from an otherwise crap-beer brewery...why dont you guys make more beer like this and less of your everyday beers?

12oz bottle at Ginger Man Southlake.
Dull amber brew with very little head.  Nose is slightly tart with oak, cherries, vanilla, vinous.  Flavor is very vinous - woody and malty.

Bottle. Pours a cloudy orange copper with medium frothy white head that lasts awhile. The aroma is cherry,oak, and funk. Thick mouthfeel with sweet cherry and nice light tartness in the finish. Easy to drink. Really enjoyed this one.

Bottle at BTBF. Pours with a hazy golden orange hued body with a retentive white head. Aromas are of white wine, huge tannin, oaky. Chewy Char. Estery, light zest, currant and cherry. Flavors are lightly zesty, white sangria, vinous, new oak, dill/celery lactone character. Some cherry. Lively carbonation. Dry, a bit boozy, lightly acidic. Very fizzy. Delicious.
Bottle.  The look is amber in color, ok off white head.  The smell is tart, fruits, nice, and wine like.  The taste is alcohol, yeast, tart, wood, and good.
Big Texas Beer Fest.  Brownish pour with a white head.  Aroma is dark fruit, spice, and alcohol.  Taste is carbonation, berries, light grain, and some tartness.

Bottle at BTBP. Brown pour. Nose is oak, must, sweetness, white grapes, grains, and fruit. Flavor is tart, oak, tannins, white grapes. Very oaky, tons of toasty notes and tannins. Excellent dry finish. Amazing beer!

Amber pour with a white head. Very fruity aroma of pear, candied apple, raspberry, and cherry. Light lemony tartness, oak, grass, and white wine. The flavor has a nice fruity sourness. Lemon, raspberry, and cherry are pronounced. Notes of pear and apple, too. Grass, a touch of oak, mild wine, and some light malt sweetness.

(12oz bottle, courtesy of Walt)  Pours a clear amber orange with a small white head.  Aroma of cherries, vanilla, and light chardonnay notes.  Flavor of vanilla, chardonnay grapes, cherries, caramel, and subtle brett with a dry oak finish.

UPDATED: APR 16, 2013 Cloudy red brown with a thin ring of head. Aroma is white wine, cherry, funk, and wood. Taste is very much the same and on the tart/sour side. Dry on the palate. This is a really good beer would love to be get some bottles of it instead of just having several samples at BTBF.

Found a couple bottles. Bit of a gusher on the first one I opened. A lot of carbonation in the glass. Everything else goes along with my previous rating. Good beer.

Cloudy dark amber beer that pours with a small to non-existent ring for a head. It has an enticing clean aroma like lichens on a stone after a sweet rain. The taste is perceived as sour malt with an oaky red wine character. The mouthfeel has a strong punchy bite thats fizzy, subdued, and a little tart. I cant even tell how strong this is so its easily drinkable esp. b/c the initial taste reminds me of a sour presukably from the wine barrel aging. Very good.
Nice amber color with no head.  Nose is alcohol, light cherries, tart, and caramel.  Smooth on the palate, caramel, cherry, dough, toffee, lightly tart finish.

Not much head results from a pour of this barrel-aged beer, even when vigorously poured.  It looks just like a Christmas Ale, deep, thick amber in color but nowhere as clear as the original Christmas Ale is.  It smells rich with cherries, but shy of a cherry-like sour red ale, somewhat thin on the nose but potent and still easy, smooth.  A light, pleasant wild yeast aroma adds to the noses complexity, but doesnt control it.  The beer is light-bodied, but powerful in the mouth.  The flavor is controlled by a slightly soured cherry flavor that ends up complimenting the beers winter warmer-like malt body very well, almost as if Saint Arnold Christmas Ale was mixed with a sour red.  What a great idea that would be, and although thats not what they did, it sure tastes like it.  Kudos to Saint Arnold for doing all of that rough legwork in taste-testing all those barreled beers, mixing and matching them, and for having the good taste in deciding on this mix.  Totally unlike Bishops Barrel #1, this is another great idea for barrel aging, yet still not too out of this world, obnoxious, or a far stretch at all.  Modest and easy, but still still of character and manages to pull off a clean and clearness despite the short-lived sour, wild finish.

12 oz. bottled poured into an imperial pint glass. Served room temperature. Tasted on 2/1/13.

Appearance: Head is nearly nonexistent, and what there is of it diminishes very quickly. There is no lacing. The body is a clear ruby. This is all absolutely consistent with the type of beer. The acidity in the cherries kills head retention, so that is to be expected.

Aroma: A fairly one dimensional nose consisting mostly of sour cherry, or cherry and some citrus acidity. However, the cask wood, which is present, does pleasantly bring the nose back to balance.

Palate: An excellent light body, which makes it very drinkable. The same mouthfeel as a Pinot Noir. The texture is thin with a slight effervescent tingle at the front end.

Flavor: The flavor lingers, which is great. It is moderately sweet to balance the cherry, but not so sweet that you lose the funk. It is appropriately funky and acidic; there is nothing too harsh.

Overall: I would drink this beer again and again. Im thoroughly impressed by this beer. This is the best thing I have tasted from St. Arnolds, which is something, because everything they make is wonderful.

UPDATED: JUN 9, 2013 Bottle. Pours bright copper. Nose is huge winey flavors. Big wine flavors and very dry. Wheres the Christmas ale? Very light body.  Interesting.  Rerate 6-9-13. Still the same rating-nice bright coloring in the flavors but overall sort of a mix/mash of styles.
user_location: Seattle still not near Beersel., Washington, USA

text: Pours clear amber with reddish hues and little to no head. Aroma or fruit and sweet oak. Tastes of sour tart cherries with a little funk from the brett and nice light sweet dry aftertaste. Overall this is a beer not expected from Saint Arnolds great sour like funky beer. Very good beer.
bottled, orange amber color with nice wine and sour cherries aroma, flavor is white wine, sour cherry, dry sweet finish

Bottle at The Holy Grail in Plano. Pours a deep red color with no real head. The aroma has a lot of dark fruit and cherry notes, as well as some white wine. The flavor is more complex. When the beer is cold I get a lot of cherry, white wine and oak character However, as the beer warms I start to get a lot more chocolate and vanilla. The alcohol is very well hidden. Medium mouthfeel and low carbonation. Excellent.

12oz Bottle- Pour is an amber color with a very thin white head that fades..Nose is cherry, oak, tropical fruits, light funk and tartness..Taste is Cherry, chardonnay, oak, sweetness,stone fruit, soft tartness, brett, dry and very low carbonation..Palate is sweet fruits;

Pours a deep tan brown .. . mild head, good spots of lacing .. . quite a bit of cherry, some wood and a light touch of funk .. . has a light mouthfeel and also is quite dry .. . will age wonderfully, good stuff .. . . 

Yeah? Well, I got a problem with the black-and-white people at the zoo.
 Who?
You know, the black-eyed Chinese people that eat sticks.
The pandas.
 "Oh! I know how to read! I know all the animals names at the zoo!" ... Yeah, the pandas.
